title: About
text:
About this site

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Introduction
text: How does statistics fit into data science?

title: Introduction
text:
Where do data come from?
Start with a research question

What is the average mercury content in swordfish in the Atlantic Ocean?
Does a new vaccine reduce incidence rates for a particular disease?
Are average hours of sleep per night related to GPA for graduate students?

title: Introduction
text:
Types of research questions
Broadly speaking, we can categorize research questions into two categories:

Prediction questions require training a model that will perform well on new data
Inference questions require a model that can assess relationships between an outcome and predictor variable(s)


In this class, we will focus on inference. Next semester, you will focus more on prediction.

title: Introduction
text:
Where do data come from?
Based on the research question, we can identify the population of interest.
Often, it is unrealistic to collect data on the entire population, so we collect a sample.
But how?

title: Introduction
text:
Sampling
Say I want a sample of five students in this class and I want to measure the proportion of the class that identify as extroverts. How could I choose five people?

title: Introduction
text:
Simple random sampling






Gold standard, but not always practical
Many statistical methods assume simple random sampling



Image source: https://openintro-ims.netlify.app/data-design

title: Introduction
text: Syllabus

text:

Statistics Fundamentals
Linear Regression

title: Introduction
text:
Learning Objectives


Fit and interpret statistical models, including linear and generalized linear models.
Connect statistical modeling concepts to underlying statistics fundamentals including probability distributions and estimation.
Map a research question and dataset to the appropriate statistical model.
Make careful and critical decisions about model building and consider real-world implications.
Communicate (through written and oral communication) model results to a broad audience.

Introduction to Modern Statistics, Second Edition by Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel and Johanna Hardin. (Available online)

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of the class, you should be able to:

apply the probability rules to a given scenario
describe in words the concepts of independence, sensitivity, specificity, and Bayes rule

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Motivation
We rely on probability to draw conclusions about our population of interest

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Probability terminology

Event: a potential outcome
Probability is a measure of how likely it is that an event occurs
The sum of the probabilities of all events in a sample space is 1
\(0 \leq Pr(A) \leq 1\)

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Probability definitions

The complement of event \(A\) is denoted \(A^c\) and it indicates that event \(A\) does not occur. \(Pr(A) = 1-Pr(A^c)\)
The occurrence of two events \(A\) and \(B\) at the same time is denoted by \(A \cap B\) and \(Pr(A\cap B)\) is known as the joint probability of \(A\) and \(B\)
The event that either \(A\) or \(B\) or both occur is denoted by \(A \cup B\). \(Pr(A\cup B) = Pr(A) + Pr(B) - Pr(A \cap B)\)
Mutually exclusive events: \(Pr(A\cap B)=0\)
Conditional probability: \(Pr(A|B)=\frac{Pr(A\cap B)}{Pr(B)}\)

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Independent Events
If knowing about the occurrence of event \(A\) does not give information about the probability of event \(B\), then events \(A\) and \(B\) are independent.
 
Mathematically: \(Pr(A\cap B) = Pr(A)Pr(B)\)
 
and \(Pr(A|B)=Pr(A)\)

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Sensitivity and Specificity
We can visualize the combination of two events in a 2x2 table and use this to calculate conditional probabilities

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Bayes Theorem
 
Bayes Theorem allows us to invert conditional probabilities. We can use it to update a belief based on prior knowledge.
 

\(Pr(B|A) = \frac{Pr(A|B)Pr(B)}{Pr(A)}\)

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Bayes Theorem Example
You have 3 coins. 2 of them are fair and one is rigged so that it always lands on heads. You choose a coin at random and flip it; it lands on heads. Is the coin you chose likely to be fair or rigged?

title: Intro to Probability
text:
Birthday Problem
What is the probability that two people in the class have the same birthday?

title: Homework 1
text:
Using the provided Qmd template, complete the following exercises and submit the document with your answers on Gradescope, which you can access through Canvas. You must show your work for all problems.

In a Japanese cohort study, 5,322 male non-smokers and 7,019 male smokers were followed for four years. Of these men, 16 non-smokers and 77 smokers developed lung cancer.

Fill in the 2x2 table for this problem:










Developed lung cancer
Did not develop lung cancer
Total




Smoker





Non-smoker





Total






What is the probability that a randomly-selected non-smoker from this group developed lung cancer?
What is the marginal probability of developing lung cancer in this group?
Are the events “smoker” and “developed lung cancer” independent?

Suppose a particular disease is prevalent in a population with 60%. The sensitivity and specificity of the medical test for this disease are both 0.9. A patient from this population is visiting the physician and is tested for the disease.

What is the probability that a person has the disease given that they had a positive test result?
Drop the given statement that the specificity is 0.9. If the sensitivity is 0.9, what is the minimum required specificity of the test to know with at least 95% certainty that the patient has the disease given that they have a positive test?

A manager at a restaurant is training her new hostess and during the discussion the new employee asks about the typical size of a group that needs to be seated. The manager says company research indicates that one of the following three probability models is appropriate.



Group size
1
2
3
4
5




Model 1
0.1
0.25
0.2
0.2
0.1


Model 2
0.15
0.35
0.25
0.25
0.1


Model 3
0.1
0.35
0.15
0.3
0.1




Identify the correct probability model and explain the problems with the other two models.
What is the expected size of a group that needs to be seated? Is this different from the most likely size?

A potato chip manufacturer decides whether to purchase a truckload of potatoes by selecting samples and inspecting them to see if they meet the company standards. Suppose that 20 potatoes are randomly selected and the company policy is to purchase the load of potatoes if fewer than 2 of the potatoes are deemed unsatisfactory. Find the probability of purchasing a load of potatoes for which

5% are rotten
10% are rotten

A soup company claims that one of its products contains 480 mg of sodium per serving with a standard deviation of 6 mg. Assuming that the amount of sodium in a particular serving varies according to the normal distribution, what is the chance that a particular serving contains:

fewer than 475 mg of sodium
at least 490 mg of sodium
Find the interval of sodium levels that contains 80% of the values for the amount of sodium in a particular serving.

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Random Variables
Random variables are variables that can take different values, and the value they take depends on a probabilistic process.
Examples:







Y=Resting heart rate
Y=congestive heart failure status (1=Yes, 0=No)




80
0


82
1


78
0


90
1


65
0

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Probability Distributions
A probability distribution is a function that maps a possible outcome of a random variable to its probability of occurrence.







Image source: https://blog.minitab.com/en/adventures-in-statistics-2/understanding-and-using-discrete-distributions

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Key Components of Probability Distributions

Support: values that the distribution can take
Parameters: values that characterize the distribution
PDF/PMF: \(f(x)\) , function whose output is a probability of a particular value or range of values
CDF: \(F(x)\) , function whose output is a cumulative probability up to a particular value
Expected value/mean: \(\mathbf{E}(X)\)
Variance: \(\mathbf{E}[(X-\mu)^2]\)

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Example



\(X\)
1
2
3
4


\(P(X=x)\)
0.2
0.4
0.3
0.1




Is this a valid probability distribution?
Is this a discrete or continuous distribution?
What is the support?
What is \(P(X=3)\)?
What is \(F(3)\)?
What is \(\mathbf{E}(X)\)?
What is \(Var(X)\)?

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Example answers

Is this a valid probability distribution?
Is this a discrete or continuous distribution?
What is the support?
What is \(P(X=3)\)?
What is \(F(3)\)?

title: Probability Distributions
text:
Example answers

What is \(\mathbf{E}(X)\)?
 
What is \(Var(X)\)?

\(Var(X)=\mathbf{E}[(X-\mu)^2]=\mathbf{E}[X^2]-\mathbf{E}[X]^2\) (do this on your own)

text:

Normal
t

title: Sampling Distributions
text: Sampling Distribution Illustration

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Central Limit Theorem
 
Let \(X_1,X_2,...,X_n\) have population mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\)
\[
\bar{X} \sim N(\mu,\frac{\sigma^2}{n})
\]
 
As the sample size gets large, the sample mean becomes normally distributed, with mean \(\mu\) and standard error \(\sigma/\sqrt{n}\) , regardless of the distribution of \(X_1,...,X_n\)

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulating the CLT in R
Recall that the rnorm function can generate values from a normal distribution
rnorm(1, mean=10, sd=2)
 
Let’s simulate taking a sample of size 10 from a population that is normally distributed with mean 10 and SD 2
set.seed(905)
NormalSample_10 <- data.frame(means=rnorm(10, mean=10, sd=2))

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Let’s generate a histogram.
ggplot(NormalSample_10, aes(x=means))+
  geom_histogram()

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Now, let’s simulate the process of taking 1000 different samples, each of size 10, and compute the mean of each sample.
Normalmeans_10 <- data.frame(means=NA)
for(i in 1:1000){
  set.seed(905+i)
  NormalSample_10 <- rnorm(10, mean=10, sd=2)
  Normalmeans_10[i,1] <- mean(NormalSample_10)
}

ggplot(Normalmeans_10, aes(x=means)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Now, let’s simulate the process of taking 1000 different samples, each of size 100
Normalmeans_100 <- data.frame(means=NA)
for(i in 1:1000){
  set.seed(905+i)
  NormalSample_100 <- rnorm(100, mean=10, sd=2)
  Normalmeans_100[i,1] <- mean(NormalSample_100)
}

ggplot(Normalmeans_100, aes(x=means)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Finally, let’s sample from a bimodal distribution.
plot(density(rbinorm(1000,35,62,5,5,0.3)),
     main="Population Distribution - bimodal",
     xlab="x",ylab="Density")

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Start with n=10
Bimodalmeans_10 <- data.frame(means=NA)
for(i in 1:1000){
  set.seed(905+i)
  BimodalSample_10 <- rbinorm(10,35,62,5,5,0.3)
  Bimodalmeans_10[i,1] <- mean(BimodalSample_10)
}

ggplot(Bimodalmeans_10, aes(x=means)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Sampling Distributions
text:
Simulate the CLT in R
Now let’s do n=100
Bimodalmeans_100 <- data.frame(means=NA)
for(i in 1:1000){
  set.seed(905+i)
  BimodalSample_100 <- rbinorm(100,35,62,5,5,0.3)
  Bimodalmeans_100[i,1] <- mean(BimodalSample_100)
}

ggplot(Bimodalmeans_100, aes(x=means)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Statistics Reflections
text:
In the MIDS program, we emphasize thinking critically about data analysis. Quantitative fields like data science are often viewed as “amoral,” but human judgment always plays a role in data collection and analysis. As data scientists, we must carefully consider the societal factors that play a role in our work. The materials presented with this assignment explore how statistics/data science interact with society at large.
This assignment connects to the fourth course learning objective: Make careful and critical decisions about model building and consider real-world implications.

title: Statistics Reflections
text:
In the MIDS program, we emphasize thinking critically about data analysis. Quantitative fields like data science are often viewed as “amoral,” but human judgment always plays a role in data collection and analysis. As data scientists, we must carefully consider the societal factors that play a role in our work. The materials presented with this assignment explore how statistics/data science interact with society at large.
This assignment connects to the fourth course learning objective: Make careful and critical decisions about model building and consider real-world implications.

title: Statistics Reflections
text:
Instructions
You are required to complete two statistics reflections during the semester. You can select any material from the list of materials below.

Begin your assignment with a header that includes your name and the title and source of your selected material
Reflect on the material selected. What did it make you think about? How does it affect your work as a data scientist? Note that you are required to engage with the material and provide your thoughts/reactions; you should NOT be summarizing the piece.
While there is no minimum word count for the reflections, you are expected to meaningfully engage with the material (2-3 paragraphs). You can use the suggested questions to get started, but you are not required to answer them in your response.
You can use Word or any other text editor to complete this assignment, as long as you submit a PDF to Gradescope. You do not need to use R/Quarto for this assignment.
In Gradescope, select the appropriate reflection assignment based on the due date. All of the assignments are already available, so you can complete them at any time!

I am always available if you have any questions or comments about the content presented in these materials. Additionally, if you come across a piece that is not on this list and you would like to use it for a statistics reflection, you are welcome to send me an email. Please include a link to the piece and a brief description of how it connects data science and society.
Note: It is not appropriate to use ChatGPT for this assignment. The task is to offer your personal reflections/thoughts; there are no right or wrong answers here.

title: Statistics Reflections
text:
Materials

  
    
      
        A Primer on Non-Binary Gender and Big Data (article)
      
    
    
      
        A Primer on Non-Binary Gender and Big Data 
        The author offers several questions you may want to consider in your response: 
        
          What potential insights might we derive from working with non-binary gender and data?
          What are the risks to gener minorities in relation to data?
          What kinds of variation do we see across culture, context, and history?
          How might non-binary gender and data deal with intersectionality (Click this link to learn more about intersectionality)
        
        Additionally, you may want to consider: 
        
          Is it always useful/important to collect data on gender? In which domains might it be more important than others?
        
      
    
  
  
    
      
        How Eugenics Shaped Statistics (article - highly recommended!)
      
    
    
      
        How eugenics shaped statistics 
        
          Consider this quote: "The separation was everything—not how much, what else might explain it, or why it mattered, just that it was there." Reflect on what this means for you as a data scientist
          The article argues that you cannot separate the science from the scientist. Do you agree?
          Reflect on the argument that Galton, Pearson, and Fisher's views are "a product of their time."
        
        
      
    
  
  
    
      
        To predict and serve? (article)
      
    
    
      
        To predict and serve? This article may be of particular interest to those interested in social justice. The authors work with the Human Rights Data Analysis Group (and Kristian Lum is a Duke alum!) 
        
          In data analysis, we often use the phrase "garbage in, garbage out" to refer to models based on bad data. How does this relate to the problem of using biased data for predictive policing?
          The last sentence states that data-driven approaches should be inclusive. How do you think this can be done? Is it possible to use biased data without reaching biased predictions?
          Can you think of other examples in which using data to predict future behavior could do more harm than good?

        
      
    
  
    
    
      
        Data sonification (podcast)
      
    
    
      
        Loud Numbers: Listen to whichever one of the podcast episodes looks most interesting to you. Also, read the FAQs under the What We Do tab. You might also be interested in the Talks and Articles listed under the Community tab. 
        
          One of the FAQs mentions accessibility. Consider the limitations of only representing data visually and how data sonification may make data more accessible.

          How might we use the other senses (touch, smell, taste
